Award.AwardTitle: Joint Optimization of Pricing, Assortment, and Fulfillment in Omnichannel Retail

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many retailers sell products both online and in brick-and-mortar stores. In such omnichannel systems, the retailers need to decide what products to offer at what prices in which channels, and how online orders will be fulfilled, either from distribution centers or from store inventory. This project will use mathematical models to optimize retailers' decisions in omnichannel systems. Specifically, researchers will identify policies that retailers can use to identify the assortment of products to be sold in each channel and their prices while accounting for fulfillment considerations such as inventory imbalance and expedited shipping. This project has the potential to positively impact retail operations of companies of all sizes. In addition, it will provide educational opportunities for doctoral and master's students, as well as undergraduate students. The latter will participate in this project through the university's Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program.

The objective of this research is to develop algorithms and identify policies that are optimal or near-optimal for decisions arising in retail operations with multiple channels. These decisions include (1) assortment and inventory policies that prescribe which products, and how many units per product, should be stocked in each store and distribution center; (2) fulfillment policies that prescribe from which store, or distribution center, online orders should be fulfilled; and (3) pricing policies that dynamically adjust the price of products sold in certain channels to maintain a balanced system-wide inventory distribution. Researchers will formulate these problems as mathematical programs and use their solutions to construct near-optimal policies. Existing literature typically only considers the problem of optimizing retail operations in brick-and-mortar stores without considering the online channel. By considering both these channels, this project will contribute to the emerging academic literature on retail operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exponential growth of omni-channel and online retail within the past decade has affected how businesses sell their products and also given rise to a wide range of challenging logistics and operations problems. Among these are the questions of product assortment (e.g., which set of products should be displayed in a store, or in a website), product pricing, order fulfillment (e.g., from which store/warehouse to fulfill the order), and inventory replenishment. Many existing legacy systems that are widely used by retailers tend to consider these interconnected questions in isolation, which may result in a significant loss in both financial and operational efficiencies. The focus of this project is twofold: (1) We want to highlight the benefit of considering (some of) these decisions jointly and (2) we also want to develop simple and scalable algorithms that can be potentially used in practice.

Some of the highlights of our works are as follows:

  • We show that there is a significant benefit in considering pricing and fulfillment decisions jointly instead of separately. Intuitively, this is so because while pricing affects total demands, fulfillment affects total supplies (i.e., the distribution of total remaining inventories across different stores/warehouses). Thus, to properly balance supply and demand, it is important for retailers to consider these two decisions jointly. Building on this important insight, we also develop a simple joint pricing and fulfillment algorithm that can be implemented in real time.
  • We show how the inventory in a network of fulfillment centers can be chosen robustly when the firm can only rely on estimates of the mean and covariance of the demands. This problem is of practical importance since the zipcode-level e-commerce demands have a joint probability distribution that is difficult to estimate.
  • We show that there is significant benefit if a retailer can optimize how products are displayed in the online storefront jointly with the fulfillment decisions. In such a strategy, the chosen display decision reflects how the inventory is distributed across the retail network. We demonstrate that such a strategy can significantly reduce the shipping costs compared to a strategy that optimizes the product display and fulfillment separately. We also develop a scalable algorithm that is easy to implement.
  •  We show that when customers return their purchases, a firm can increase profitability by using dynamic pricing together with a strategy of reshelving resalable returned products. This is an important finding since customer returns are the reason why e-commerce retail has such a high cost. We develop a novel algorithm that can be implemented in real time.

This grant is distributed across seven papers (some are published, and some are still going through peer review process). It is used to support the research of three PhD students: two males and one female. One male student has graduated and is now working as a research scientist at a top US retailer, focusing on the area of omnichannel and e-commerce logistics; the other male and female students have also graduated and are now Assistant Professors at reputable business schools in Canada and US, respectively.
